description: From Middle English principal, from Old French principal, from Latin prīncipālis.

adjectives.description: principal (comparative more principal, superlative most principal)

entries.meaning: Primary; most important; first level in importance.
examples: Smith is the principal architect of this design.
The principal cause of the failure was poor planning.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, Latinism) Of or relating to a prince; princely.
(mathematics) Chosen or assumed among a branch of possible values of a multi-valued function so that the function is single-valued.
examples: Two is the principal square root of 4. Both −2 and +2 are square roots of 4.

entries.meaning: (finance, uncountable) The money originally invested or loaned, on which basis interest and returns are calculated.
examples: A portion of your mortgage payment goes to reduce the principal, and the rest covers interest.

entries.meaning: (Canada, US, Australia, New Zealand) The chief administrator of a school.
examples: The important administrative figure to the teacher is the school principal.

entries.meaning: (UK, Canada) The chief executive and chief academic officer of a university or college.
examples: Unlike the students, Principal Robertson, who now resided almost alone in the College, continued to use the accustomed route on his visits to the Old Town; and it “became the joke of the day that from being the principal gate it had become only a gate for the Principal.”5

entries.meaning: (law) A legal person that authorizes another (the agent) to act on their behalf; or on whose behalf an agent or gestor in a negotiorum gestio acts.
examples: When an attorney represents a client, the client is the principal who permits the attorney, the client′s agent, to act on the client′s behalf.

entries.meaning: (law) The primary participant in a crime.
(Canada, US) A partner or owner of a business.
(music) A diapason, a type of organ stop on a pipe organ.
(architecture, engineering) The construction that gives shape and strength to a roof, generally a truss of timber or iron; or, loosely, the most important member of a piece of framing.
The first two long feathers of a hawk's wing.
One of the turrets or pinnacles of waxwork and tapers with which the posts and centre of a funeral hearse were formerly crowned
(obsolete) An essential point or rule; a principle.
examples: Set two classes of monitors to question each other; so that one may try to outquestion the other. Explain to them the principal of every subject they have to teach.

entries.meaning: A dancer at the highest rank within a professional dance company, particularly a ballet company.
